Hi Rich - 

Rich is right. Many of us have tried a few things over the years but mostly without satisfactory results. We hate to say to try something that's not going to give you the correct results. One of the best results I've ever had was when a friend of mine would offer to wear a tsuba around his neck for awhile. He worked in a gym and his body sweat (ugh) worked wonders on some tsuba and didn't work on others (depending on the steel). Personally, I've never tried to used one of the traditional formula that can be found. 

Ancient coins...sounds interesting! 

Ron
STL

  From: Richard Turner

  Hi Kim, I don't think anyone will answer that, an inherently dangerous 
  question that could only lead to tears. You will be told 99.9% of the 
  time, it is best left to the experts.

  So the answer would be, We DON'T repatinate parts of our swords, we send 
  them to polishers and they do it.

  cheers

  Rich Turner

  Kim Ghobrial wrote:

  > Hi All,
  > No one responded to my questions.  Can someone please tell me how you
  > guys repatinate your parts of the swords?  Also, what is recipe for
  > doing it?
  >
  > Sincerely,
  > Kim
  >
